title: Amazon Web Services
description: Static Hosting on AWS with S3 Amplify and CloudFront

children.value: Deploy Nuxt on Amazon Web Services
Static Hosting on AWS with S3 Amplify and CloudFront

AWS stands for Amazon Web Services.
S3 is their static storage which can be configured for Static Site Hosting. CloudFront is their CDN (content delivery network)
Nuxt app on AWS w/ the Amplify Console is powerful and cheap.
First, push your Nuxt app to the Git provider of your choice. Then, visit the
header if you haven't used Amplify Hosting before, otherwise click the
On the "From your existing code" page, select your Git provider and click
On the "Add repository branch" page, select your repository and the branch you want to deploy. Then, click
On the "Configure build settings" page, click the
button under the "Build and test settings". Change the following:
The settings should look like this once you are done editing them:

props.code:
version: 1
frontend:
  phases:
    preBuild:
      commands:
        - yarn install
    build:
      commands:
        - npm run generate
  artifacts:
    # IMPORTANT - Please verify your build output directory
    baseDirectory: dist
    files:
      - '**/*'
  cache:
    paths:
      - node_modules/**/*

children.value:
version: 1
frontend:
  phases:
    preBuild:
      commands:
        - yarn install
    build:
      commands:
        - npm run generate
  artifacts:
    # IMPORTANT - Please verify your build output directory
    baseDirectory: dist
    files:
      - '**/*'
  cache:
    paths:
      - node_modules/**/*
Then, your application will deploy. This may take a few minutes.
are green, click on the URL that the Amplify Console provides to view your site.
Nuxt app on AWS w/ S3 + CloudFront is powerful and cheap.
AWS is a death by 1000 paper cuts. If we missed a step, please submit a PR to update this document.
We'll host super cheap with some AWS services. Briefly:
cloud data "bucket" for our website files
can be configured to host static websites
We'll push the site like this:

props.code:
Nuxt Generate -> Local folder -> AWS S3 Bucket -> AWS CloudFront CDN -> Browser
  [      nuxt generate       ]    [         gulp deploy          ]
  [                         deploy.sh                            ]

children.value:
Nuxt Generate -> Local folder -> AWS S3 Bucket -> AWS CloudFront CDN -> Browser
  [      nuxt generate       ]    [         gulp deploy          ]
  [                         deploy.sh                            ]
First, we'll generate the site with
to publish the files to a S3 bucket and invalidate a CloudFront CDN.
Our deploy script needs these environment variables set:

props.code:
deploy.sh       -  run `nuxt generate` and `gulp deploy`
gulpfile.js     -  `gulp deploy` code to push files to S3 and invalidate CloudFront

children.value:
deploy.sh       -  run `nuxt generate` and `gulp deploy`
gulpfile.js     -  `gulp deploy` code to push files to S3 and invalidate CloudFront
Make a S3 bucket and configure it for static site hosting
Setup build script in your project
AWS: Setup your S3 bucket and CloudFront Distribution
tutorial to setup your S3 and CloudFront
You should now have this data:
For step 3, we need to create a user that can:
Invalidate the CloudFront distribution (propagates changes to users faster)
Create a programmatic user with this policy
with your S3 bucket name below. This policy allows pushing to the specified bucket, and invalidating any CloudFront distribution.
get an access key and secret
You should now have this data:
Laptop: Setup your project's build script

props.code:
#!/bin/bash

export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID="key"
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY="secret"
export AWS_BUCKET_NAME="example.com"
export AWS_CLOUDFRONT="UPPERCASE"

# Load nvm (node version manager), install node (version in .nvmrc), and npm install packages
[ -s "$HOME/.nvm/nvm.sh" ] && source "$HOME/.nvm/nvm.sh" && nvm use
# Npm install if not already.
[ ! -d "node_modules" ] && npm install

npm run generate
gulp deploy

children.value:
#!/bin/bash

export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID="key"
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY="secret"
export AWS_BUCKET_NAME="example.com"
export AWS_CLOUDFRONT="UPPERCASE"

# Load nvm (node version manager), install node (version in .nvmrc), and npm install packages
[ -s "$HOME/.nvm/nvm.sh" ] && source "$HOME/.nvm/nvm.sh" && nvm use
# Npm install if not already.
[ ! -d "node_modules" ] && npm install

npm run generate
gulp deploy
runnable and DON'T CHECK INTO GIT (deploy.sh has secrets in it)

props.code:
chmod +x deploy.sh
echo "
# Don't commit build files
node_modules
dist
.nuxt
.awspublish
deploy.sh
" >> .gitignore

children.value:
chmod +x deploy.sh
echo "
# Don't commit build files
node_modules
dist
.nuxt
.awspublish
deploy.sh
" >> .gitignore
4.3) Add Gulp to your project and to your command line

props.code:
npm install --save-dev gulp gulp-awspublish gulp-cloudfront-invalidate-aws-publish concurrent-transform
npm install -g gulp

children.value:
npm install --save-dev gulp gulp-awspublish gulp-cloudfront-invalidate-aws-publish concurrent-transform
npm install -g gulp

props.code: ./deploy.sh

Deploy Nuxt on Amazon Web Services
Static Hosting on AWS with S3 Amplify and CloudFront

AWS stands for Amazon Web Services.
S3 is their static storage which can be configured for Static Site Hosting. CloudFront is their CDN (content delivery network)
Nuxt app on AWS w/ the Amplify Console is powerful and cheap.
First, push your Nuxt app to the Git provider of your choice. Then, visit the
header if you haven't used Amplify Hosting before, otherwise click the
On the "From your existing code" page, select your Git provider and click
On the "Add repository branch" page, select your repository and the branch you want to deploy. Then, click
On the "Configure build settings" page, click the
button under the "Build and test settings". Change the following:
The settings should look like this once you are done editing them:

props.code:
version: 1
frontend:
  phases:
    preBuild:
      commands:
        - yarn install
    build:
      commands:
        - npm run generate
  artifacts:
    # IMPORTANT - Please verify your build output directory
    baseDirectory: dist
    files:
      - '**/*'
  cache:
    paths:
      - node_modules/**/*

children.value:
version: 1
frontend:
  phases:
    preBuild:
      commands:
        - yarn install
    build:
      commands:
        - npm run generate
  artifacts:
    # IMPORTANT - Please verify your build output directory
    baseDirectory: dist
    files:
      - '**/*'
  cache:
    paths:
      - node_modules/**/*
Then, your application will deploy. This may take a few minutes.
are green, click on the URL that the Amplify Console provides to view your site.
Nuxt app on AWS w/ S3 + CloudFront is powerful and cheap.
AWS is a death by 1000 paper cuts. If we missed a step, please submit a PR to update this document.
We'll host super cheap with some AWS services. Briefly:
cloud data "bucket" for our website files
can be configured to host static websites
We'll push the site like this:

props.code:
Nuxt Generate -> Local folder -> AWS S3 Bucket -> AWS CloudFront CDN -> Browser
  [      nuxt generate       ]    [         gulp deploy          ]
  [                         deploy.sh                            ]

children.value:
Nuxt Generate -> Local folder -> AWS S3 Bucket -> AWS CloudFront CDN -> Browser
  [      nuxt generate       ]    [         gulp deploy          ]
  [                         deploy.sh                            ]
First, we'll generate the site with
to publish the files to a S3 bucket and invalidate a CloudFront CDN.
Our deploy script needs these environment variables set:

props.code:
deploy.sh       -  run `nuxt generate` and `gulp deploy`
gulpfile.js     -  `gulp deploy` code to push files to S3 and invalidate CloudFront

children.value:
deploy.sh       -  run `nuxt generate` and `gulp deploy`
gulpfile.js     -  `gulp deploy` code to push files to S3 and invalidate CloudFront
Make a S3 bucket and configure it for static site hosting
Setup build script in your project
AWS: Setup your S3 bucket and CloudFront Distribution
tutorial to setup your S3 and CloudFront
You should now have this data:
For step 3, we need to create a user that can:
Invalidate the CloudFront distribution (propagates changes to users faster)
Create a programmatic user with this policy
with your S3 bucket name below. This policy allows pushing to the specified bucket, and invalidating any CloudFront distribution.
get an access key and secret
You should now have this data:
Laptop: Setup your project's build script

props.code:
#!/bin/bash

export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID="key"
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY="secret"
export AWS_BUCKET_NAME="example.com"
export AWS_CLOUDFRONT="UPPERCASE"

# Load nvm (node version manager), install node (version in .nvmrc), and npm install packages
[ -s "$HOME/.nvm/nvm.sh" ] && source "$HOME/.nvm/nvm.sh" && nvm use
# Npm install if not already.
[ ! -d "node_modules" ] && npm install

npm run generate
gulp deploy

children.value: # Load nvm (node version manager), install node (version in .nvmrc), and npm install packages
runnable and DON'T CHECK INTO GIT (deploy.sh has secrets in it)

props.code:
chmod +x deploy.sh
echo "
# Don't commit build files
node_modules
dist
.nuxt
.awspublish
deploy.sh
" >> .gitignore

children.value: 4.3) Add Gulp to your project and to your command line

props.code:
npm install --save-dev gulp gulp-awspublish gulp-cloudfront-invalidate-aws-publish concurrent-transform
npm install -g gulp

children.value: npm install --save-dev gulp gulp-awspublish gulp-cloudfront-invalidate-aws-publish concurrent-transform
// Sensible Defaults - gitignore these Files and Dirs
// wait for CloudFront invalidation to complete (about 30-60 seconds)
// create a new publisher using S3 options
// publisher will add Content-Length, Content-Type and headers specified above
// If not specified it will set x-amz-acl to public-read by default
No CloudFront distribution configured - skipping CDN invalidation
// create a cache file to speed up consecutive uploads
